description.text:
A small 12v LED holder (31/32mm festoon bulb) with mounting screw holes to fit under the Kodama Trinus Z rail...The bulb can rotate down to point to the print bed (and backlights the extruder to help with viewing the print gap). I used a 6x sms SMD 3528 31mm auto Festoon Dome Light Bulb... but much brighter ones are available on eBay (search 31mm LED festoon).
The LED holder screws to the end of the underside of the Z rail via 2 off M1 12mm screws (as used on the Trinus end-stop micro-switches). There are holes in the print to push through the wire leads and make contact with the festoon bulb (a tight fit ensures electrical contact, but you could solder them).
Obviously it has other applications: the screw hole centres are 9mm apart.

description.text:
I've had ProStruders with Prometheus system for a while now and they work very well. However, sometimes when there's a filament jam or wrong feed sequence is triggered, the powerful steppers can push filament with such force that it 'spills' from the sides as the filament path is somewhat open. Also PTFE tubes aren't that rigid, making this problem bit worse.

So designed these filament guide parts. They replace following parts from the original ProStruder:

  • 4x M3 Washers
  • 3 Acrylic Tube Guides
  • 8 Acrylic 7.5mm Washers
    You can figure what to do with those if you decide to do this mod :).

Assembling (see https://www.distechautomation.com/pages/pro-sys-assembly#2.03):

  • the lower guide part (has bolt hole through the side) needs to be inside the idle part. The bolt that mounts the idler to the motor needs to go through the idler and the guide part.
  • after inserting the top assembly, slide the top guide part to the bolts (instead of the two original tube guide parts). For orientation, see that the gear and idler holes match.
  • proceed as in the original instructions
  • when inserting the PTFE tubes to top and bottom, make sure to push them all the way to the guide parts

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

I used PLA, but PETG or ABS might be better.

Remove supports. Use 2 mm drill bit to drill the filament holes open, they are intentionally not fully through to make slicers do 1 bridge layer = better quality of the 4mm -> 2mm hole transition. Also clean the bolt holes and 4mm tube holes to make sure the parts are easy to assemble.

comments.text: Thanks for this design.  I just ordered the Prometheus System and was concerned about the weakly constrained filament path as well as the possibility that the Bowden tubes could be sucked into the gears.  This mod solves both problems!  I'll be printing up two sets of these and installing them in my ProStruders from the beginning.
comments.author: TimStough

comments.text: Unless I'm missing something, it looks like the filament path is closed.  The hole cut doesn't go all the way through to the Bowden tube side.
comments.author: TimStough

comments.text: That is by design, you don't need to use supports when printing the smaller hole. That one layer is printed with bridging, making the result cleaner. You need to use 2mm drill bit anyways to check the paths. Learned this trick from Thomas Sanladerer.
comments.author: TimStough

comments.text: Beautiful, thanks for the explanation.  I will use this trick elsewhere!

title: Easy 3D printable Game Arcade 7 inch TFT (low print time)

description.text:
Why?

I designed this arcade for a low print time for the Anet A8 but it will be printable on other printers aswell. Use wood filament or any other material!
I wanted to built a full game arcade but many I found used too much material and had too many components to print!

This is a tailored arcade to easily 3d print. I designed it to be minimalistic, yet still a lot of fun to build.
You do not want to waste time and expensive material so I have made the wall thick enough to be stable and the sizes small enough (yet good) to reduce print time.
I used a TFT HDMI screen with the hdmi connector on the right side, so I had to make sure that I offset the screen due to HDMI cable Management. Because of the small size and the TFT screen I recommend using this screenpanel if you use a TFT screen with the connector on its side. If you use another screen you can simple use another layout.

Features:
-I squeezed the sizes onto my print bed.
-The plates are max. 21x21cm which means you can print it on almost any 3d printer since most printers are 22x22 cm.
-Can be printed in 20-22 hours (average)

Only 8 components to print!

Please not that this depends on your nozzle size and quality setting.
Nozzle size 0.4mm quality moderate (wood print)

-controlpanel.stl 3-4 hours
-left_panel.stl 5-6 hours
-right_panel.stl 5-6 hours
-front_panel-start-select.stl 4-5 hours
-bottom.stl 7 hours
-back_plate.stl 7 hours
-top_plate.stl 1-1.5 hours
-7_inch_tft.stl 1-2 hours

Electronical components

-Rasperry pi 3
-7 inch TFT HDMI
-Joystick USB controller
-Joystick Controller kit
-Powerbank (for portable play)
-Adapter
-Portable USB Speaker

Design video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6666Bvzr244

Don't forget to credit me!

If you use this add a link to this page! I spent a lot of time designing it!

description.text:
The stock focuser on the Celestron Astromaster 130EQ telescope doesn't have enough back focus in order to attach a DSLR camera to it. Everything online says that you either need to replace the focuser with something with a lower profile (which I couldn't find anything online that was compatible) or you have to move the primary mirror significantly forward.

So, I set out to try to design a lower profile focuser that would allow a DSLR to focus and would re-use as much of the existing hardware as possible. This re-uses the eyepiece holder, the focuser knobs, the metal plate that tightens the focuser knobs pinion gear against the rack on the eyepiece holder, the metal coverplate, the 2 screws to hold those pieces on the focuser and the 3 screws and nuts to attach the adapter plate to the scope itself.

I printed in PLA at .2mm layers. It prints in two parts and is held together by 6 M3x10 screws and 6 M3 nuts. There are two versions of the adapter plate. One has a border to hold the nuts, the other doesn't. I printed the version without the nut holders and found it a bit of a pain to get the screws threaded on the nuts. I have not printed the other version yet, but it should make it easier to get the screws and nuts to lined up. The other part is the Focuser itself. It's got a couple of included supports that will need to be removed in order to get everything assembled, but they should come away easily.

title: Best sfic core repinning tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple sfic core repinning tool. It is probably not as good as a metal version, but it works. Print it sideways, so that the hole for the core points upwards. You probably have to clean all the holes for the pins with a small needle file.
Print it in a transparent color PLA. Looks nicer and you see what you do a bit better ;).
Tolerances are pretty small, so it needs precise printing.
The lid is for catching the parts when you push the plugs, springs and pins out.
For pushing out and also repinning and resetting the pins and plugs, you can use small allen keys or welding wire (I would attach a little handle, maybe with an end stop).
I made this for a friend and it is tested. Sfic core repinning is still not that easy without some practice ;).
Have fun :), foxxy

The 5015 fan mount was modified to be slightly thicker and larger around to accommodate captured nuts for all the screws, cuz I hate trying to hold them while I tighten the screws.

The Titan Carriage was modified to use a cable chain for wire management and the BLTouch for bed leveling.
I know that some others have incorporated either the SN04 inductive sensor or the BLTouch into similar designs, but first I have never had good luck with the SN04 and second, the other designs had features for adjusting the sensor which I thought was responsible for the difficulty I had with keeping the SN04 adjusted. My mount of the BLTouch is static and requires that you adjust the Z offset in EEPROM.

Finally, when I removed the SN04 cabling and added the BLTouch cabling I found that it was still a PITA, not as bad as having to unthread the wiring and rethread the new wiring but still a PITA.

I had recently watched a video where Nillabean talked about adding a cable chain to his Original Prusa i3 MK2 and he mentions this open cable design, https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8r558hYwxKj, it is so simple to use. You layout your cable, assemble your chain, connect your chain to the circuit board box and then lay the wiring in the chain and finally insert the locks. DONE! So I had to modify:

  1. the Circuit board box
  2. The X-Carriage
  3. The Titan mount
    to fit the new links.

UPDATE Nov 24, 2017:
I had a filament jam on the E3Dv6, due to an overlong retraction, and had to remove and re-add the Titan several times. Any of you who may have built this Titan mount probably have some unkind words for me due to the PITA that was forced based on the original design. I sure did.
There are several problems with the original design:

  1. You have to mount the carriage onto the bearings before you could mount the Titan and E3D.
  2. The location and orientation of the Cable Chain mount caused it to interfere with the routing of cables and access the screws for mounting the Titan and stepper motor.
  3. The Cable Chain still used a fixed plate and grove for cable management.
  4. The BLTouch mount interfered, much like the Cable Chain interfered with access to screws for mounting the Titan.
    So I returned to the drawing board to address all of this.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Fusion 360 to the rescue

For the remixes, I started with the STL file and added my new parts from scratch, I use the standard Fusion 360 workflow.

Hardware

I did not keep accurate track of the lengths of the screws I used, but the mounting screws were the same M4's HICTOP used for the carriage that came with the printer.

The BLTouch and the fan mount were secured with M3's.

Wiring and connectors

I prefer to have connectors close to the carriage. I feel this makes it easier to remove/replace components without requiring extensive rewiring.

The connectors I used were from either the BLTouch kit, a Hiitchi connector kit (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0188DMF3A/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1) or 3-pin JST (https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/jst-sales-america-inc/XHP-3/455-2219-ND/1651017)

The BLTouch was supplied with a short cable, which would not reach to the circuit board, so I had to add new wires for that. I first tried to use a ribbon cable as I had seen in some youtube videos. I found the ribbon cable too stiff and hard to work with. I chose to use 24 AWG silicone wire instead.

I cut the wire longer than needed and then braided them using a 5-way plait.

What's New

This iteration now has two parts:

  1. The base plate as before, but without the mount for the Titan and stepper motor.
  2. A new orientation and type of connector for the Open Cable Chain. This one uses a removable clip to hold the cables in place and is mounted in-line with the left-side of the plate.
  3. The Titan and stepper motor are now mounted on a separate interlocking plate which may be slid into the base plate. This new mount engages the base with a rounded hourglass mating pattern which proves to be both snug enough to prevent "wobble" and to maintain the orientation of the hot-end even during long prints.
What may still be wrong with this build
  1. As was pointed out to me earlier, using a horizontal chain will eventually result in a slagging chain. This is caused by the constant polishing of the interface between the individual links.
  2. Because the connector on the base plate is now lower, by a full link-width, the cable is no longer horizontal and may make the individual links wear more quickly. I have several changes in mind which may correct this but I am far from ready to discuss any of them.
  3. Converting to the new design may result in one or more cables being too short and may require replacement of those cables.
  4. A Chain that flexes along the vertical axis would be preferred, and the solution used by the Original Prusa i3 community may be the answer. However, I am not able to route the cables through the back of the base plate as the Prusa did due to the size of the pillow bearings. I am currently experimenting with both this solution and at least one other.
Build warning!!!!!

The tolerances in the mating of the base and motor plates are very tight and need to be for the mount to work. I printed my pieces on an Original Prusa i3 MK2s.

description.text: Beechcraft Logo for Flight Simulator
Thinkercad
After converting an original Mendel into a Prusa, I had scads of 624z Bearings left over. I designed this to use them on smooth rods.

1) Print as many as you need.
2) Take 3-624z bearings, insert into slots, put an M4 x 16 screw in each of the bearings.
3) Put nuts on the screws and tighten until the screw is no longer moving back and forth. Any tighter and the plastic will clamp down on the bearing, causing it not to move.
4) Slide over an 8mm smooth rod and move back and forth multiple times to loosen the item up a bit. It will be stiff when you first put it on, but after a while, it moves freely.

comments.text: If you change the design slightly, you should be able to use very cheap aluminium square beams instead of expensive, heavy round beams. The aluminium beams I can buy at the metal shop here cost around 2 euros per meter and have very low deflection over length.

title: Spaceing and accuracy test cylinder print down to 0.15mm

description.text:
This is a quick check print I have made. The little cylinders have a spaceing towards the block. Spaceing is checked for 0,30 / 0,25 / 0,20 and 0,15mm.
Most popular well-calibrated printers get stuck at 0,2mm. If you make it down to 0,15mm you are lucky.
The cylinders have additional spacing at the bottom to get the parts loose even when the first layer might be thicker than all the others.
The whole block can be used to calibrate and check the XYZ dimension as the block is 15x15x60mm big.

Note: On my Vellemann Vertex I got the spaceing working down to 0,15mm and an accuarcy of 0,05mm for the overall block as well as a nice closed surface.
But this took a lot of calibration effort....

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1 or better

Infill:

20% up to 35%

Notes:

Try to calibrate your infill and XYZ distances very well before printing this.
Do not be too surprised to have stuck cylinders even at the 0,3mm spaceing.

Even when changeing the filament type you might have to take into account different fialment diameters and quality. A well manufactured filament has a fixed diameter and it takes only one measurement and adjustment in the settings of your SW.
But lousy filaments are available which start to change their diameter every meter of the spool.

author: MSpencer

title: JAVA Application - to Import STL objects to OpenSCAD with point values for editing

description.text:
This JAVA application is helpful to get a 2D or 3D object from a simple SVG sketch.

Usually you can import a stl 3D printer object directly into OpenSCAD. You can resize it, you can transate it, rotate it, everything you want.

But you won't get the points used in the object. to edit the lines or single points you must have these values within the scad command list.

What I made is a program to convert the XML based information from SVG-files to point values for OpenSCAD.

  • import the values
  • set a specific point for every single value
  • create polygon 2D-objects
  • create optional 3D-objects
  • calculate the center points of single objects within the SVG (each line inner and outer, circles is a single object, in XML identifiable by the M-index for starting position and L-index for line vectors)
  • get information to min and max values of the object

What you can do now is import a STL file, make a 2D projection of it (maybe cut into slices) and export this result from OpenSCAD to a SVG file.
Now open this file with the java program, select the source, and specify the target scad file, let the tool work and open the SVG file and create a new OpenSCAD project.
When you open this new file you will see every object.
Per each there is a single module named p with a rising number.
I have rounded each value to 1/100mm automaticly.
You can exclude single points from the polygon, insert new points, move points, get simple measurements (the center of rotated objects could not be measured by simple X-Y-distances, look at the red arrow markers)

Version History

2017-09-27
the modules and parts will be named with the name of the file. if multiple generated file are used (use and use ) it's confusing which "p0" is ment.
so it is now file1_p0 and file2_p0.
only with center-point-names and modules. p000... p9999 ff. are within the modules, would not matter.

There is a error caused by a unknownhostexception when parsing the xml-(input)file.
Solution is: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4002885/unknown-host-exception-while-parsing-an-xml-file. New version, 2017-10-01

title: Filament (1.75mm) force measuring hook for tension spring balance

description.text:
Please print two pieces and screw them together with M4 screw and nuts.

Put a spring scale with the hook on one side and the 1.75mm filament is clamped right in between the two parts.
Then you can get your extruder pulling the filament in and read the force in Newton (or kg whereas 1kg has the equivalent of 10N) from the scale until it slips.

On my Vellemann Vertex K8400 I changed the extruder and gear to an MK7 type.
Therefore the initial force from 45N (4,5kg) was improved to more than 70N (7kg).

description.text:
UPDATE: Printed and finished, turned out awesome!

Couple notes to guide your success:
1: The bolts are scaled at 100% to their corresponding holes in the .STL file. I did this due to differing shrink factors for different filaments and printers. I printed mine in 3dMars plain white PLA.

Bolts were printed vertically with the knobs on the print surface, .06 layer height, .08 walls, 50% fill, 50mm/s speed, 210C extruder and 60C bed temp. I also used an additional cooling fan (desk fan) which seemed to help with thread definition.

In addition, I scaled the bolts at .95 on the X & Y axis, with the Z at 100%, which required very minimal fitting for a tight, smooth threading. (mostly had to file the openings on the vice body and sliding jaw, bolts were fine)

I designed this simple table top vice in Tinkercad to have a useful tool for working with small objects. Mine is still printing, so I cannot yet comment on the performance of the vice, but this is my first big design, so I wanted to share it! (assembly instructions below)

Please feel free to share any feedback or recommendations and let me know how yours turned out!

I will be uploading my finished pictures, along with any updates (if necessary)

Thanks!

To assemble
1: insert drive bolt into base

2:Thread bushing up drive bolt until it matches up with its recess on the body. Do not over-tighten/check to make sure the drive bolt can still spin freely.

3: Slide the moving jaw onto the track recessed into the body and turn drive bolt to thread into the jaw.

4: Thread clamp screw/bolt into clamp portion of body.

5: Test fit the vice in its planned location, affix optional clamp "gripper" if necessary.

6: Once fit and function tested, glue drive bolt bushing to drive bolt (not the body)

7: That should about do it! let it dry and let me know how it works.

I wear Crystal 1 day Contact Lenses which like most lenses come in a 30 day box that is not ideal to store and easily access every single day.
I have looked all over to find a better way to store them in the bathroom while making them easily accessible but still safely out of the way. I could not find even a single solution for storing my lenses.

As a result I took to design a solution in Fusion 360 and then purchased my first 3D printer. After trying to design a holder for all 30 pairs of lenses I realized that was not necessary. So I designed this one to hold just 7 days worth of lenses.

I have modified this design since printing it as sometimes because the lenses are in packets that are not all the same they can fall off the rails. I therefore increased the size of the rails from 2mm to 3mm on each side which should solve the problem.

This may fit other lenses but I cannot check that. The size of the lenses this is designed for is W=32mm D=38.5mm H=10mm

Screw holes are placed in the back of this but I actually ended up just using cheap double sided foam tape to stick it to the wall.

author: MSpencer

title: pneumatic extruder clamp, carriage adapter, and solenoid bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Pneumatic extrusion printing is actually very simple on almost any open source 3D printer. All you have to do is make this pneumatic extruder and set up post-processing scripts to turn on an output - this output opens a valve and applies pressurized air to dispense material.

Pressure
The hardest part may be a consistent source of high pressure air. If you have an air compressor/tank or house air at a lab/shop this will work best. I'm also working on an adaptation of a 2L soda bottle, these can hold up to 100 psi! (50psi safely) even still, use at your own risk). You should not need much more than 30 psi, and we will use a 30psi max regulator to the pressure we need (only ~10-15psi). Again the flow is: pressure source/regulator, solenoid to control flow, dispensing syringe.

Electronics
You do not use the existing extruder motor, but you do need an extra output like a controllable fan that can handle ~500mA (some fans are only 20-50mA). Alternatively, you can use the extruder heater output, but you will not be able to heat and control a nozzle tip and you may have to make firmware modifications to make it work. You will have to make sure a safety feature is disabled that kills the printer if the heater is on but an increase in temperature is not detected. This can be dangerous for (hot) plastic printing though, so use at your own risk! Some printers don't have this enabled by default, so for example the Monoprice Mini does not have an extra fan or open source firmware, but can use the extruder with this setup.

Toolpath
To automate the use of these outputs, you will have to install python and point your slicer to scripts that add lines of code (only a semicolon between scripts with the full path). One script turns the solenoid ON AFTER an UNretraction (make sure retraction is >0 in your slic3r) and unretraction should only and always happens when you want to start dispensing. Another script turns the solenoid OFF BEFORE a retraction to stop dispensing (if it stops AFTER the retraction it will leave a blob at the end of a line). A final script may be helpful to give a small pause (100ms) to let the material start extruding or there may be a delay and gap in the line. These scripts will run after slicing a file and insert the respective lines, and the order is critical (pause, on, off).

Extruder
For the physical setup, you will need the printed parts, solenoid valve, and some cheap dispensing syringes/tubing/connectors. The design includes a carriage mount for an anet a8-style printer, but I included the *.step file so you could more easily modify it. I also made a bracket to hold the solenoid so both it and the regulator could be on the top of the frame (pictures to come!) You need to use a 3-way solenoid - if you use a 2-way, the pressure will be trapped in the syringe and ooze, rather than venting.

Calibration
I've included custom calibration scripts that are in coarse, medium, and fine increments. You may need to change some of the coordinates if you printer size is different. First run the coarse calibration - it will begin with a loop tat the average speed that will allow you get a ballpark pressure with the regulator. It will then extrude 5 lines at the lowest speed through the highest. Whichever line is closest to the appropriate width is the correct speed to use with the medium and/or fine calibrations. It's really helpful to have a camera mounted directly to the extruder - the absolute cheapest "6 LED webcam" (~$4!) on ebay or amazon work great for this because they can be manually focused close like we need. You might get 2-3 because they are pretty cheap and you might get one DOA. Additionally, for the exact type linked, you remove the base, tap the stem with m3 thread, and screw into it with the bolt that retains the dispensing syringe. I've included "@pause" commands for use with Repetier Host to simplify taking pictures after printing calibration lines.

Bed Leveling
I highly recommend using auto-bed leveling with a conductive nozzle and metal bed to eliminate variability measuring line width. I may post this as a separate thing with details about how to enable it in the firmware. The physical setup is easy - fix a 3/16" thick 8x8" aluminum sheet from mcmaster-carr to the bed with binder clips. A precision ground surface or extreme flatness is not necessary (you will end up scratching it a bunch anyways). Then connect one alligator clip to the bed and one to the needle, and use those two wires in place of a typical mechanical endstop switch.

title: E3D Titan Aero Mount For Alunar M508

description.text:
This part is designed to attach an E3D Titan Aero extruder to an Alunar M508 (Prusa i3 clone). It may fit other printers.

If the spacing of your X carriage 8mm rods is 45mm center to center, this will probably work for your printer. I also uploaded the Fusion 360 model file, so you can edit it to suit your needs.

You will need the following hardware:

1) SC8UU - QTY 3 (8mm linear bearing with "platform")
2) KW11-3Z - QTY 1 (limit switch)
3) M4 x 15mm screws - QTY 2 (belt attachment points)
4) M4 nuts - QTY 4 (belt attachment points)
5) M4 x 8mm (approx.) screws - QTY 12 (for attaching mount to bearings)
6) Small cable ties/zip ties - QTY 2 (don't be a slob)
7) E3D Titan Aero Extruder - QTY 1 (duh)

  • = If you have an Alunar M508 (or similar) printer you probably already have items 1-4

9/26/17
The parts cooler in the picture is this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2234811. The mount portion of Thing # 2234811 easily snapped in half, to make it a "one sided" cooling fan. I also trimmed the duct as the creator of the thing describes. It's not ideal but it gets the job done. The Titan Aero kit came with the longer screw that I needed.

title: Taranis Pistola: A pistol grip RC controller with a Taranis QX7 inside!

description.text:
Slight update: The back part now allows for both trim rocker switches to be installed and the top now has slight beefier tabs to accommodate screws from the back.

I got tired of super expensive commercial surface receivers for my RC cars. At the same time, they only offer typically 4 or less channels. That was all fine and good for the standard RC car, but crawling rigs and semi-trucks often have additional features that could benefit from having additional channels.

I love my Taranis for quads and other aircraft but I never quite got the hang of driving with sticks.

Soooo, I bought a new Taranis X7, tore it apart, printed a new shell, and I can now present the Taranis Pistola!

This allows for up to 8 normal channels of control, plus you can link receivers together to get 32 (I think, I've never done it). You also get all the flexbility of the Taranis ecosystem like OpenTX, which allows you to mix and twist the controller to do just about anything you need.

Receivers are typically less than $30, with some 8 channel receivers in the low $20's.

As for the design, I used a wheel and trigger cluster from a standard Traxxas remote, mostly because they are available cheap (or free if you or a friend has an unused unit lying around). You need to clip a plug from the Taranis and solder it to the potentiometer leads from the Traxxas cluster. I made a design decision to omit the other two proportional controls (the right stick) and two of the trim rockers (although one is located on the back of the remote as you need it to enter USB mode). I used a standard LiFE battery that is commercially available for $10. All pcb's are retained from the original radio. The antenna comes soldered directly to a pcb, so I desoldered and added a Ufl./IPX connector to the board (there are pads for this purpose) or you could order an SMA to bare wire and solder directly to the board. I didn't want to re-use the stock antenna because I wanted some flexibility in antenna choice.

If you can solder (or learn) this is decently straightforward. I posted a lengthy PDF with instructions that should get you most of the way if not all the way there. Start to finish this is about $120 + filament, which is pretty cheap for an 8 channel surface radio, especially since one does not exist commercially!

Feedback is appreciated!

description.text:
Couldn't find the cool alignment tool that I downloaded. So, tested my rudimentary skills in TinkerCad and designed this one. Looks cool in Orange. Print Two or just jog One from side to side. Place the square end over the lower Y rod. Carefully lower the X rod - slowly -you will bend the rod if you let it get out of control. Once the Y rod is down, ensure that both sides are equal distance by measuring with the tool. Disable motors and adjust the high side down by twisting the right or left X motor manually. Then, check the opposite side to ensure both sides are the same distance. Remember, the rods are aligned. The bed is "leveled" - not really- it is also aligned on all 4 bed corners with respect to the printing nozzle. But, it is called "leveling the bed." The rod alignment process is often called "leveling the X-Y rods."

Leave some comments and pictures if you "make."

title: Shark Head Pen Pencil holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Shark head was found on Pinshapes but it was not designed for holding pens and pencils. So I took it and redesigned it by hollowing out the inside in Tinkercad for that purpose. I also scaled it up and then post finished it by sanding, filling, more sanding and then priming and airbrushing the details. I used acrylic paints and for the clear I used Behr gloss cement sealer from Home Depot. Turned out beautiful and there is about six coats of clear with wet sanding in between coats. The print took 18 hours at 4800 mm/min and a layer height of 0.2. Top and bottom layer of 3 with a 15% infill and supports. Be careful taking out the supports as you can break out a tooth. I did as you can see but the good news is that sharks do loose their teeth! Printed with PLA from Inland.

comments.text: what products did you use to get the excellent painted look on this shark?
comments.author: terrace_dr

comments.text:
Hi Mike
Ya I painted using a badger airbrush and acrylic paints.
The key is to sand the print using 600 to 1500 grit sanding pads. I found mine at a local hobby shop. I believe they were by the brand Tamiya.
Then use a primer, also by Tamiya and sand again. All the painting is free hand and from light to dark. Although I painted the sharks sides by using a ripped piece of paper and airbrushed over the ripped edge. I also mixed my own greys to get what I thought looked close to pictures of sharks I downloaded from the net.
For the gloss. Well I started with Tamiyas can gloss spray but it looked horrible..Then I used cement sealer wet finish by Behr from Home Depot. I knew it would not ruin the acrylic paint and I sponge brushed it on. About 5 coats.

title: Robo 3D R1+Plus Molex Print Bed Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a way to be able to disconnect my printer's bed heater without the usual amount of disassembly. Eventually I settled on a Molex Mini Fit Jr dual row connector, so I created this adapter to mount the plug on the back of the printer. It requires cutting out one piece of the vent grate to make room. I accomplished this with a needle file and it was not much trouble at all. Through a few iterations of the adapter design, however, I still couldn't reliably get the plug to stay in place when plugging in the heater, so I added a couple little tabs and now it's nice and solid.

Was it more work than it's worth? Probably. Still, if this is a feature you'd like to add to your printer, I've already done the design work for you. Just be sure to be careful assembling everything so all the circuits match up correctly. Black wire goes to black wire is not going to help you on that cable. I used a metallic silver Sharpie to help orient mine properly.

My ideal next step would be to get a second bed so I could swap them out and start another print while one finishes cooling. Whether or not that will play well with z-offset and auto-leveling, though, who knows?

author: shocker828

description.text:
Gaming token for the Flaming Sphere spell from Dungeons and Dragons, 5th edition.

The circular base is 1" diameter.

Painting Tips

Paints required: primer, black, plain red, plain white, plain yellow, and either charcoal/black or electric blue.

Prime, and base-coat using either charcoal/black or electric blue. Choose charcoal/black for a flaming sphere that looks like a chunk of coal spouting flame, or choose blue for one that looks like a sphere of pure flame. Let dry.

With plain red, drag your brush over the sphere, using enough pressure so that the nooks and crannies retain the base color.

While red paint is still wet, mix in some yellow to the red paint, and drag the brush over the sphere again, this time a little lighter. Continue adding yellow and lightening the brush until you're only very lightly brushing the sphere.

Do a final coat of the sphere using very light yellow (almost more of an off-white, really). This coat can either be done using drybrush technique, or using the same technique used above with a very light touch and not much paint in the brush.

Paint the base black.

description.text: See also http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47973 for a version with an LCD screen. It's that time. We're approaching Solar Maximum and chances of seeing the Aurora Borealis / Northern Lights are increasing worldwide. Seeing the aurora is usually difficult, due to a lack of accurate information specific for your location. Add poor locations, light polluted skies, clouds and sometimes only a 30 min window of opportunity..., it can be like finding a needle in a haystack. Many think Auroras are limited to the Arctic. But, unless you live at the equator (and it's even seen there occasionally), you too can see it if you're in the right place at the right time. The aurora monitor is a technology I've been using for a long time to take photographs of the aurora (attached). I've updated this technology for Thingiverse and made it a stand alone Arduino based unit which you setup for your location. An RGB Led indicates if there's an aurora active for your location with 30-60min advance warning. The strength of the storm is indicated by the auroral color of the Led. Accuracy is around 95%. Detailed information can be Tweeted too. Here's the feed for my location: https://twitter.com/AuroraAdec) The Inukshuk was created from a 2D grayscale image using OmNomNom Creator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24639 This was printed on a Tom using Jetty Accelerated Firmware at 100mm/s: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17855

This project is a very easy build, requiring only basic soldering skills, network setup and arduino skills. You need:

  • Arduino capable of Wifi or Ethernet, these ones I've tested:
    http://www.robotshop.com/productinfo.aspx?pc=RB-Lin-40&lang=en-US
    http://arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardEthernet/

  • 10mm RGB Common Anode LED, I used this:
    http://evilmadscience.com/productsmenu/partsmenu/329

  • Resistor x 3, if using the above LED, then 100 Ohm x 2, 150 Ohm (for red)

  • Miscellaneous: A strip of header pins, wire, heat shrink or tape

  • 9V (12V Max) Power supply for your Arduino (also a USB can be used for power)
    • Source code can be found here: https://github.com/jetty840/AuroraMonitor Viewing tips for the Aurora can be found in the attached instructions.

Print the remaining parts and assemble as per "Assembly.skp". Note I printed "Heart Base.stl" in white for the first 4mm height to match the color of "Base.stl", then switched to red for the remainder of the print. If you use Sailfish firmware on your Replicator 2, you can program the printer to pause at 4.2mm while the print is in progress and allow a change in filament color. Hope you like it.

description.text:
This extruder setup is made for the HICTOP Prusia i3. From stock, I had 190mm of safe x axis travel. Because of the fan size, I have had to reduce the usable travel to 180mm. Check the drawing to see if it will fit your printer and take note I have upload my marlin firmware with bed leveling and eepromm enabled. This was designed to allow me to easily switch between direct drive extruding and Bowden drive extruding so you will see it is fit with a Bowden style E3D V6 version hot end. The filament drive is very exposed which has made it sooooo much more convenient to change filaments opposed to the stock version that came with the printer. The assembly reuses all parts from the printer other than some M3 bolts and M3 nuts. The heat break fan/hot end clamp was designed around a cloned E3D V6 so if you have any issues with fitment let me know. Enjoy!

PS. I am using 40mm x 40mm x 20mm Noctua fans. They are really quiet and come with little silicone plugs that fit and secure fans to fan ducts without any screws. I am using the 12v FLX version. Have not had any issues yet (more than a month) withe the heat break fan being connected directly to 24v.

description.text:
• Object History and Revision Process
    The beginning roots of this project, and the incentives, had all begun with the goal of creating a Bionicle mask that could also be compatible with Lego parts. Settling on a specified set of goals/issues in need of a solution, what had followed was the creation of a few rough sketches that could give a generalized visual representation of what the final product would look like. During this, one of the main focuses was in creating a consistent theme of tubing throughout the mask, and the creation of a design had allowed me to move on to digitally designing the model, for which I used Tinkercad's digital software. Meanwhile using Tinkercad, the entire model had been based around an axel rod on the inside of the mask that was key in making the project, as by the original intent, Lego compatible. With the wrapping up of digital design and printing the model into the real world, the product had only one, major, failure. The inside of the mask had several components sticking out that got in the way of connecting it and the axel rod, the main point of attachment, had been too short for parts to reach, which all made the possibility of the mask being compatible with Lego parts near impossible.
    As a result of this failure, I addressed the issues through the brainstorming of several ideas. My chosen solution on fixing the stated issues was to empty the inside of the mask and extend the axel rod, digitally, since the specialized tools in a digital program allowed for reaching a higher level of quality and easiness in editing the model. The application of these changes unto my final 3D print had in turn made it succeed in its intended purposes of being compatible with Lego parts and working as a mask, which is where my designing process came to an end for this project.

  • Printing Instructions
    -When preparing to print the object, you should follow specific scale measurements of 34.63 mm in height, 47.00 mm in width, and 56.00 mm in length.

-The model is a single component, therefore there should only be a single print to obtain the full product.

-Supports should be turned on for the printing of this object, and it should also be noted that the supports take near close amounts of plastic to that of the actual model.

-When removing supports, the use of knives or other possible, small, "tools" like needles would be suggested to remove supports from tiny areas.

remixed_from.author: cparrapa
remixed_from.title: Otto DIY build your own robot

description.text:
Greetings students and parents,
Here you will find the CAD files used to create our GIFS Otto as well as the class lessons.

Robots are completed. It was exciting and enjoyable to see what all the children created.

The Otto_GIFS robot is an opensource project derived from the Otto robot. To see the history of the Otto GIFS robot click the remixed from designs to see a list of other creators that helped grow the Otto community.

Syllabus
  • Oct. 24th - Prototyping
  • Legotasitic Break
  • Nov 21st - Manufacturing
  • Nov 28th - Programming and Robot Dance Party
  • Dec 12th - Otto_BT Firmware & Zowi App setup
Resources
  • Rowbits (Firmware) - https://github.com/LucidWolf/Rowbits/
  • Arduino IDE - https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
  • FreeCAD - https://www.freecadweb.org/
  • Bitbloqs (Block Programming for Arduino) - http://bitbloq.bq.com/#/

Body

-Head - No change
-Body - Extra 5mm of body height (room) to help children with packing wires for battery replacement
-Body Spacers - (New) between the motor and the body. They have two purposes. The first is to trap the screws on the motor for easier installation. The second is to lock the speaker and switch in place without the use of epoxy or hot glue.
-Legs - No change
-Feet - Reduced spacing to make joint tighter. A slot is added to assist in attaching the joint because of the reduced space. The servo arm no longer requires cutting. This change eliminates children and razor interaction. :)

Hardware and Software

-No change to base Otto except blue tooth module HC-06.
-Rowbits firmware is used to enable both Bluetooth and the serial port for debugging. (Still Beta)

comments.text: This is amazing welcome to add to the Otto builder community group (http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/ottodiy/things)

comments.text: Hi great work what are the things next to the body for?
comments.author: cparrapa

comments.text:
Those are the spacers that sit under the body SG90 servos. With SG90 servos the servo face should sit flush with the body when they are used.
If you thread them on the screw before you hand the servos to the children for installation the screw is trapped to the servo; so the screw can't get loose and disappear into the void. (Full disclosure this happened to me too many times as well.)
The two specialty ones trap the 8mm switch and speaker so you don't have to glue those pieces to the body. Its still a pain to get the motors in and the switch i might try to combine the for and aft spacers into one piece that easily aligns with the body and holds the switch some how so it just fits without much work.

title: Adjustable DC42 Mini Differential IR Height Sensor BLTouch adapter mount

description.text:
I designed this little adjustable adapter plate to mount my DC42 Mini height sensor board to my E3D X-axis Carriage where the BLTouch would normally be installed.
This works out great as the large hole allows a screwdriver to be inserted to raise and lower the sensor. I couldn't find any mounts for this board that allowed for adjustment and fiddling with the Z-Axis Offset can be a real pain.

It is also designed to protect the sensor from the majority of filament disasters as the board as mounted facing away from the extruder.

The Mount (included) has been remixed from this design as I lost ~20mm on the left due to my X-axis endstop being too far over.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170721

Other hardware required:
1 X MINI DIFFERENTIAL IR HEIGHT SENSOR
3 X M3 hex nuts
2 X M3 x 10mm hex bolts
1 X M3 x ~25mm hex bolt (+/- 5mm)
1 X M3 washer (optional)
1 X 5mm OD / 3.3mm ID x 15mm spring (spare bed spring)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed the sensor mount piece laying flat with supports as I was experiencing issues with it breaking when printed standing but without supports.

Printed with 100% infill for rigidity - may not need.

Cleanup and assembly

Depending on how well your printer handles supports, you may need to sand the sensor board a bit to get it to slide smoothly inside the upper mounting piece.
Don't overdo it as too much clearance could cause the lower piece to not fit snugly and cause your sensor to not give repeatable readings.

Install hardware:
Insert the two hex nuts into the hex shaped recesses in the top piece. They should fit snugly so as not to fall out.
Insert a hex nut into the slot on the lower half.
Slide the lower half up into the upper half.
Insert the long bolt through the hole in the top of the mount and capture the spring in between the two parts.
Thread the bolt into the nut and apply some tension on the spring.

Mount the sensor into the lower piece with the capacitor facing out.
Mount the entire assembly to the x-axis carriage using the 10mm bolts being careful not to knock the hex nuts out of their holes.

Lookup dimensions

I first went to David Crocker's Blog to get the exact dimensions of the IR sensor:
https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/

Get BLTouch dimensions form antclabs website:
https://www.antclabs.com/bltouch

Measure height from BLTouch mounting flange to bed.

Sketch in Fusion 360

Transfer your dimensions from paper to a sketch in Fusion 360

BLTouch mounting flange sketch IR Sensor mounting plate and overall height Bringing it all together Push, pull, cleanse, fold, and manipulate.

Extrude the sketches into two bodies.

Push in a small amount of clearance, check the fit using the section analysis.
Print out the first run and test everything.
Make changes until everything is perfect and five iterations later you have the finished piece!

Lower section where the sensor mounts Upper section that mounts to the X-Axis carriage Section analysis to check for clearance

The semi-circle cut out from the top left of the dongle holder allows the iPhone camera and flash to be used unobstructed if the user choses to adhere the clip to the top of their phone. author: Webweave

title: Zamperla Giant Discovery Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the pretty dimensionally accurate model of a Zamperla Giant Discovery 40. In real life, this ride stands 91 feet tall and is 122 feet long and 82 feet wide. This model is on a scale of one foot to one millimeter meaning it (when printed and assembled correctly) stands 91mm tall and is 122mm long and 82mm wide respectively.
This has been in the works for a very long time and has gone through countless iterations and reworks to make it as accurate as we can while still be printable. Overall we think the result is a very nice talking point and a nice little model to print and assemble.

There are only 18 pieces to print in total and many are repeats. For the full model, print the quantities listed below:

8X Floor Panels

1X Engine Female

1X Engine Male

1X Pendulum Hinge

1X Pendulum

1X Ride Vehicle

2X Support A

2X Support B

1X Base

Now that you're done printing...

What you'll need: Hot glue gun, hot glue sticks, flush cutters, PATIENCE (the glue dries/cools VERY slowly).
Warning: Not allowing the glue to dry/cool properly will make the connections weak and the model may pull itself apart.

Assembly:

1) Remove any and ALL support material.
2) Do not paint anything before assembling.
3) Take the 'Engine Male' piece and thread it through the 'Pendulum Hinge'.
4) Lightly line the inside wall of the 'Engine Female' piece with hot glue.
5) Quickly press the 'Engine Male' piece and threaded 'Pendulum Hinge' in making sure the mock reduction boxes are flat. We recommend flipping them upside-down like a table to assure they dry together evenly.
6) Set aside what you just worked on.
7) Take the 'Pendulum' piece and thread the 'Ride Vehicle' piece right side up (the way it printed) onto the rod such that the large flat circle on the bottom of the 'Pendulum' piece is nearly flush with the bottom of the 'Ride Vehicle' piece.
8) Apply a small amount of hot glue to the top of the 'Pendulum' piece.
9) Quickly affix the 'Pendulum' piece to the 'Pendulum Hinge'.
10) Take one (1) 'Support A' and one (1) 'Support B' piece and glue each into one box in the 'Base' piece facing inward in both the X and Y direction. (towards the center).
11) Take the other ride assembly you previously assembled and place a dot of glue on each side of one side of the engine.
12) Affix them respectively one dot of glue to one connection point leaving a tiny bit of space for the pendulum to swing.
13) Repeat steps 10-12 for the other side.
14) slide in the floor panels.
15) Paint the model or leave it whatever color it was printed in.
16) ENJOY!

If you have any questions don't hesitate to ask. :)

description.text:
The Imperial Navy relies on a modular hull for most of its classes of cruiser. Four side-slots and two spinal mounts allow for an exceptional variety of weapons bays while the armoured prow can take torpedoes, nova cannons, and even hydraulic-powered rams.

Ideal for Battlefleet Gothic and Epic. For ideas on building configurations as well as Battlefleet Gothic game rules, I recommend the specialist arms forum:
http://www.forum.specialist-arms.com/index.php?board=7.0

description.text:
Hey guys, building off the Rain City begleri Fidget slinger idea of placing bearings at the base of your sets I designed two shells to take an R74, and an R104 bearing. Print at the finest resolution your printer can handle. Might require some clean up as any 3D print does if there is any stringing due to the small part size.

Included are files for Monkeybarz compatible sets (using the R74 bearing), and the AO2 hardcore guts system (using the R104 bearing)

My suggestion is to use shielded, unlubricated (or cleaned) bearings, no need to get fancy beyond that.

Place the outer seat towards the top of the begleri, then the bearing, then the inner seat (since it will be tighter around the cord).

Happy slinging!

title: BL-5C / BL-5B Charger / Lipo Charger Phnoe Battery

description.text:
Ich habe dieses Lipo Ladegerät für die BL-5C und BL-5B Akkus entworfen. Habe ihn selber in ABS gedruckt was nicht so gut geworden ist, was ich aber in PLA nachdrucken werde und für den Druck empfehle. Das Lademodul ist ein TP4056 für 1S Lipos und bringt einen Ladestrom von 1A was aber runtergeregelt werden kann bei Widerstandswert wechsel. Den gefederten Anschluss habe ich mit einfachen Federn und 1,5qmm Draht realisiert. Die 1,5qmm Drähte sind zusammen mit Lackierten Kupferdraht auf ein kleines Kupferplättchen aufgelötet. Gedruckt habe ich ohne Support was aber auch mit Support gedruckt werden kann, da unterm USB Anschluss ein kleiner Einschub für das Lademodul ist. Mit Kleinem Loch im Deckel für die Ladestands Led´s.

Was Benötigt wird:
1x TP4056
2x Federn Länge ca. 22mm Durchmesser ca. 4,5mm
4x M2 x 8mm Schrauben
Lackierte Kupferdraht
1,5qmm Draht

I Designed this BL-5C and BL-5B Lipo Charger. My ABS Print does not come out good i recommend Print this in PLA. The loading module is a TP4056 for 1S Lipos and brings a load current of 1A but you can adjust down loading current by change resistance value.
The springy connection was realized with simple springs and 1,5qmm wire. The 1.5qmm wire is soldered together with varnished copper wire. I printed without support but you can print with support because there is a small insert for the loading module under the USB hole. With small hole for the charge level Led's in the lid.

What you need:
1x TP4056
2x springs length ca 22mm diameter ca 4,5mm
4x M2 x 8mm Screws
painted copper wire
1,5qmm wire

author: oke96

title: Small Heat Bed Adjustment Knobs for Creality CR-10S4

description.text:
The Creality CR-10S4 (which is the larger version of the CR-10 with a 400 x 400 x 400mm build volume) has a different construction than the normal CR-10, so the large wagon-wheel-style bed adjustment knobs that are so popular with CR-10 owners won't work. Since the standard knobs are pretty uncomfortable to use, I decided to design some more comfortable ones that will fit the S4. Just remove the knobs that came with the printer and press fit them firmly into these knobs.

After designing these, I found that there was a pretty similar knob already available here, but they are a bit different and were intended for the regular CR-10, so won't show up in searches for the S4, so I'm going ahead and uploading my version.

comments.text: Printed these knobs, a perfect design that makes the bed adjusting a comfortable and simple task. Thanks a lot for saving our fingers :-)

description.text: I prefer to have my spool holder off to the left away from the printer's wires, but I found that when you put a full 1kg spool on it, the control box will have a tendency to tip over until some of the filament has been used. You can counteract that by placing something heavy (like another spool) on top of the box, but I decided to design this stabilizer to solve the problem. Just slide it onto the rear of the control box, avoiding the rubber feet and screws, etc. This fits my control box tightly, but of course it's difficult to know how different settings and filaments will be. This will also work on the CR-10 S4, and presumably the S5, but I don't have the S5 to check.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing! Printed it and now the filament is in a much better place - providing more clearance for the filament so that it does not bind like it was doing. The stabilizer is solid - my guess is even three full rolls of filament won't tip this bad boy over! :)

title: remixed fooyabt for X and Y belt of the CR-10 or other 2020 2040 rails

description.text:
ok so I got in my toothed idlers today and decieded to upgrade my CR-10 with a fooyabt tentioner since they are great tentioners and the CR 10 has a plate that the 2020 rail is connected to and the original fooyabt can't fit in to so I cut the chunk that was hitting the plate away in meshmixer and boom new X tentioner having adjustbale belt tentioners is a quick and easy way to improve print quality you can't really get the perfect tention using the stock stuff and incase you were wondering I haven't noticed a giant leap in quality from changing to the toothed idlers over the flat ones but I can add speed and get the same quality prints and they do reduce the belt noise a little I paid about .80cents a piece for the toothed idler barrings and I think they were worth it (20theeth 5mm bore gt2/6mm belt)

EDIT
ok after a bit i wanted to make my cr-10 quieter so i got stepper dampeners and as i was adding them my old X case broke i looked at the file and found an error so I corrected it then edited it so it looked better and did the same with the Y and Dfr2923 remixed the puller i'd advise using that one rather then the standard cause the idlers fit better here's the link https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2672859

The beginning

The future?

title: Z Axis Holder for Igus Bearing

description.text:
This is based of Scot 3D's HEVO design.

I modified it to be able to clamp the Igus RJ4JP-01-12 bearings in. Each bearing can separately clamped with 2 screws.

The problem with Igus bearings are if they are not precisely aligned, they will stick to the rod.
To avoid this, I put the holders for 10 minutes in the oven by 75°C with the rod inserted. After that they run perfectly smooth.

Update: Added a Version with Bearing grooves for better grip.

I lost about 0.5 mm from the vertical height (about 2.5% and well within the listed +/-5% of the material) but found that I had to carefully file the end of the headband thinner to fit the socket, even with the socket on the model being slightly oversize. Additionally, all the holes needed to be cleaned/bored out with a drill to size.

description.text: Variations on the 'rodblock' used by Grado headphones.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Models A and B are modelled after the plastic 'rodblocks' of the Grado headphone 'Prestige' series and are made from measurements of the originals.

I've added a 3mm hole to allow a short (8mm length) hex socket head screw (6mm head) to be added from the inside so that it will engage the hole on the end of the Grado steel headband. I've found that with shrinkage when printing with PLA that an M3 screw will just cut into the plastic and doesn't need to have the hole threaded.

Both A and B have raised lettering. Model A has something close to the original, but at 0.5mm, the result from my inexperienced printing is not that great. Model B has a different 'font' that has produced better results (for me).

Model C is based (very roughly) on the rodblock design from the Grado HP1000. The lettering is recessed and there's a hole on the outside face (beside the letter) for a thumb screw to be added to tighten against the rod to prevent movement. Dimensions are close to models A and B, above as I don't have access to an HP1000 to measure.

All 3 models are designed to be used with an existing Grado steel headband (cross section 6.5mm x 1mm) and to accomodate a Grado rod (3.2mm / 1/8"). The dimensions of the model, for the headband socket, are 6.6mm and 1.1mm, but between slicer approximations and shrinkage, I needed to clean and file parts to fit. Printing at a scale of 1.1 : 1 made the holes an easy (maybe even loose, in the case of the rod) fit, but also increased the outside dimensions (as expected) to the point where it was clearly bigger than the original. YMMV. HTH. No user serviceable goods or parts inside.

I found boring out the rod hole with a 3mm bit (to clean print lines) then using a 3.3mm bit for approx 6mm from both top and bottom created an easy fit with a tighter area in the middle that allowed the rod to be moved, but with enough resistance to avoid accidental movement.

Filing the burrs off the end of the steel headband was necessary, as was cleaning the interior of the headband socket with a (very) small file (a cut down emery-board/diamond-file and a section of 'jewellery saw' blade).

Printing vertically produces better holes for the headband and rod. Printing with the lettering up produces better letters and better holes for the thumbscrew/s

I had the 'C' model rodblocks and some gimbals/yokes printed at Shapeways in stainless/bronze. I lost about 0.5 mm from the vertical height (about 2.5% and well within the listed +/-5% of the material) but found that I had to carefully file the end of the headband thinner to fit the socket, even with the socket on the model being slightly oversize. Additionally, all the holes needed to be cleaned/bored out with a drill to size.

This is a simple 1.75mm filament guide, for use on the in and out sides of an aluminium Mk8 extruder. It has a 2.5mm ID guide hole, and an external M6 thread.

I needed it after I upgraded my CR-10 to an all-metal extruder. It must be printed precisely at 0.1mm layer height, 100 infill with no support, and it should go without saying that being a printed thread, be very gentle with how its inserted - it will snap EASILY if over tightened - only tighten it as much as necessary to do the job. I would advise against winding it in to any plastic extruder bodies as plastic to plastic threads can gaul up easily, and would further suggest that an M6 nut be used to chase up and down the thread a couple of times prior to use, to ensure that if it does break (usually due to underextrusion), it only breaks inside a nut, and not the housing you intend it for...

I used it on the incoming and outgoing side of my Mk8 and have found it works like a charm for keeping the filament nicely guided :)

A dumping ground to show off some of the parts to anyone curious for the DeltaGear (name is a W.I.P., suggestions welcome) printer I'm designing. The source files will be released once the machine is finished and I get a chance to tidy them up, right now the code is messy, full of useless comments and unused variables/blocks of code.

Feel free to ask questions, I'll be happy to answer. Also, no guarantees the STLs here will come together to form a working machine. I'm constantly tweaking parameters and not necessarily changing them back, so the parts were all rendered with different machine sizes in mind. This is just a dumping ground to show progress on the machine and get some feedback from people interested.

print_settings.Notes:: ABS

description.text:
This is a completely revised Knuckle coupling for G scale garden Railways.
Video is here: https://youtu.be/kimp_JnspIU

I was not satisfied with the performance of my previous designs, and so have completely revised this version. Operation should be clear in the video.
There is also a "fixed" version of the knuckle that is for carriages etc and is a simple one piece part with integral plastic springing. These connect easily to each other and to the servo operated version.
Coupling TO a train can have the moving coupling either open or closed. With it closed, more force (speed) is needed to connect. With it "open", coupling can be done at very low speed, but the alignment of the two couplings is more critical.
I used my RC controlled Tram for the videos.

The "cutout" versions of the housing and internal body will be needed for some locos, unless you want to cut the loco body to fit the "standard" fully enclosed version.

The iges files can be found at https://grabcad.com/library/servo-operated-knuckle-coupling-1

1 Oct 17, made a very small tolerance change to the disconnect lever servo holes, to make it easier to fit the servo horn, plus I have moved the "connection axis" of the coupling 1.2mm to make for better coupling on the track. This revised the Main Hook and the Fixed Knuckle "FIXED_KNUCKLE_7DEG.st" part.
FYI, the 7 degrees refers to how "open" the fixed knuckle is. With a o degree open part, the knuckles lock so tightly they cannot be easily parted. 7 degrees was a nice compromise. Locks well, but also allows for release when required.

To fit the Fixed knuckle to your trucks and coaches you will need to print (one of) the LGB housings. these are here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1989545
Chose the housing that works best for your truck/coach etc.

Printer:

Kossel XL with Magnetic couplings

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layers

Infill:

35%

Notes:

ABS

Assembly and notes:

The only part than needs to be realigned for printing is the moving knuckle, which should be printed 180 degrees rotated, so the "large" part is on the bed, and the "small" part is printed above it.
Supports are essential for the main body, and need careful removal once printed.

The "top link" is not strictly needed, but ensures that the 0.6mm staple used to hold the knuckle to the main hook is the correct size. I Marked a pair of long nosed pliers with a mark to get this dimension right. If the staple is not the right size, the moving knuckle will not work correctly.
One end of the knuckle can be bent to secure it, but the other must be filed down or it will interfere with the disconnect lever movement later.

The lock wire is made from 0.9mm paperclips. This must be very free to move when assembled. The best assembly process is to bend the main locking feature first and assemble it to the hook, checking it operates freely before bending the counterbalance end and soldering on an M3 nut. Check that everything works before proceeding!

The two "internal bodies" need to be glued (acetone or cyanoacrylate) to the main body.

The Disconnect Lever has a cut out for a 3mm dia by 2mm magnet that helps keep the locking wire in the "lock" position. The magnet is held in place with cyanoacryate.
The slots for the servo horn will need to be opened a bit with a screwdriver to fit the srvo horn, which will need to be cut down so it does not interfere with the main body or the screw that holds the main body to the loco.

Push fit the Hook assembly into the main body. then fit the small lock body above it. This will mainly engage with the loco coupling pin, but keeps the hook assembly in the correct position.

Fit the disconnect arm to the servo and cut down the servo horn, then test fit the servo on the main body, and check the servo operation. It may be necessary at this stage to cut or bend the lock wire to get smooth operation.

Remove the servo and disconnect lever and fit the main body to the loco.
Replace the servo, re check for operation and put the wiring in the groove on the outside of the internal body.
Fit the main housing and secure with two 1.7mm *10mm screws.

All the parts Wiring fitted outside the "internal body", well away from the servo and the disconnect lever Add a mark to your long nose pliers to get the "staple" dimension right. It is very important that this part is the correct dimension. a correctly made staple fits the top link exactly. First fit of the lock wire, it should move easily. You can fit the knuckle at this point and check movement. Counterbalance weight (an M3 nut) fitted before soldering and removing excess wire.(note, a large blob of solder works also works well as a counterweight, and can be easier than trying to solder stainless steel nuts. Main body screwed to loco. Moving knuckle fitted and staple wires cut short so they do not hit the servo actuator arm Servo and actuator arm fitted for testing. Close up of the wiring positioning (on another model) before the housing is fitted. You should find that you can gently move the servo by moving the disconnect lever. Fit the housing and screw it just tight enough so that the servo is held gently.

This was designed using Fusion 360 (thank you Autodesk !)

This is a fully revised version of my earlier designs. It was much easier to design using F360, as I could make copies of the interconnecting knuckles and check their interfaces, and if I needed to change a feature on one part, the copy was changed as well.

This shows two couplings nicely connected, but also that the servo horn needs to be cut down!!...

description.text:
A medium sized boar designed with D&D in mind. Sized for 28mm games so should fit neatly on 1 inch squares.

It's been designed to be printed quickly and reliably, using a faux-2D style. Each step of detail is in multiples of 0.6mm, so should print well using 0.2 or other layer heights. When someone with actual painting skill (not me) paints them, they turn out quite nice.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

An ogre for DnD or other 28mm RPGs. It is designed as a 'large' category, so should fill 2x2 1-inch squares once on a base. As one of the early-game large humanoids, I felt it an important mini to design ASAP. That, and I needed an alternative "Gentleman Ogre" model with a top hat for my own game.

This is part of my 28Chibi project, which is a set of DnD minis that can be printed quickly, reliably and simply with most 3D printers. The detail steps up each 0.6mm, allowing you to print at 0.2, 0.3 or other amounts that are clean denominations of 0.6. I tend to use 0.12mm for the cleaner edges

comments.text: Really impressive work.  :)

A yuanti halfblood for a recent DnD game. This one was sized to be large, so if you want it the proper medium size it will need to be shrunk about 75%. Most details should still come out fine, but I haven't trialed it.

This is part of my 28Chibi project, for prints that are reliable, fast and easy on the printer. The detail steps up at multiples of 0.6, so it can be printed at 0.2, 0.3 or other sizes that are a common denominator.

Just a simple little snake. By default it is sized as a medium creature for a 28mm game, so fits neatly within a 1 inch square. Can be easily sized to large (for say a giant constrictor) or small (for other tiny snakes).

It's been designed to be printed quickly and reliably, using a faux-2D style. Each step of detail is in multiples of 0.6mm, so should print well using 0.2 layer heights. When someone with actual painting skill (not me) paints them, they turn out quite nice.

remixed_from.author: pparsniak
remixed_from.title: Smart bearing block - common lm8uu bearing block replacement

description.text:
Update 28/9 -17: New base "v1.1 Spring loaded SC8UU - Base". Bearings was found not centered on rod, corrected in new version.

Remix of pparsniak's "Smart bearing block". Great idea which works surprisingly well. The original SC8UU/LM8UU bearing lacks a good enough preload and the tolerance fit between the rods and the bearing are not as good as could be. The igus drylin bushings also have this issue, which for me actually were worse than the original LM8UU bearings. The "smart" bearing have adjustable preload, which mean that the dimension and tolerance of the rod is less of importance.

I printed the original version but I wasn't happy with using rubber bands or the screws, so the main change is that this have a spring to set the preload. Along the way I also made a few other fixes/upgrades:

  • No need for washers.
  • The same base to rod center as the SC8UU.
  • Thicker base to fit button head hex M3 bolts for the angled bearings.
  • A side surface for Y-axis limit switch to hit.
  • Optimised for 0,4 nozzle and 0,45 extrusion width.

BOM:
3x 623ZZ ball bearings
1x Spring (OD 7,5-8mm, ID 5-6 mm, ~4 mm length)
2x M3x8mm (minimum length)
2x M3x16mm (minimum length)
2x M3x25mm (minimum length)
6x M3 nut (preferably Nyloc)
(4x M4 nuts for part assembly, min. M4x8mm or preferably M4x10mm bolts)

The spring I used is the same as for the heat bed on the Anet printers cut down to length. Nyloc nuts are strongly recommended for the two nuts clamping the spring, washers and/or loctite thread-locker might also work. When setting the preload the general tip is that it is fine if there is some resistance when moving the bearing, it should enough so that the ball bearings are rolling and not slipping on the rod. The rods should be cleaned of any lubricant btw.

I would say that this solution is best suited for the Y-axis/bed, as the centre of gravity is centered and the bed will rest down on the fixed ball bearings. For the A8 X-axis/hot end-carriage the weight of the carriage will press partly on the spring loaded bearings, which might be less rigid.

Resolution:

0,1

Infill:

15-35%

Notes:

Recommended ABS or PETG, mine are printed in ABS. Supports might be needed under the holes on the base and under the ring groove on the plate.

title: Balancing robot with etched PCB shield

description.text:
Balancing robot with printed wheels and structural parts. It uses a Arduino Uno, accelerometer/gyroscope, and a etched motor/servo PCB shield that I made. Here's a video of it in action
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LAWjUlzAYf0&feature=plcp The final robot is quite a bit different from the first prototype. You can see the progression of this project here:
www.jddorweiler.appspot.com/electronics.html#robot I've wanted to make a balancing robot for a while but I was always turned away by the cost of all the parts. I tried to avoid using any expensive electronics or motors and instead tried to use common parts that other might have lying around. This is pretty much my first arduino/programming/PCB project so I'm sure there is room for others to improve it. Using servos was a cheap alternative to much more expensive geared motors but they're also a bit slow. This means that the robot can only recover from small pushes. The PCB was designed using Fritzing http://fritzing.org/ with help from http://www.fubarlabs.org and code is at http://github.com/jdorweiler/BalancingRobot The board has the H-bridge, which can control two DC motors or one stepper motor, accelerometer/gyroscope, and two servo connections. The PCB isn't required but I did it for fun. The three iterations of the robot used a DC motor, stepper, and servo so I though it would be nice to make a board that can handle any of those. I got a lot of the code and good information was found from
http://www.arduino.cc/cgi-bin/yabb2/YaBB.pl?num=1284738418/all
and
http://www.kerrywong.com/2012/03/08/a-self-balancing-robot-i If your making the PCB and using a different accelerometer board, make sure to check the pins. They're probably not the same and the one I used. This would be easy to change in the Fritzing file though.

Parts
-Arduino Uno
-4x 15 to 20mm M3 bolts and nuts or similar to attach the servos
-2x continuous rotation servos http://www.adafruit.com/products/154
-Accelerometer/gyroscope board. Any will work. I used this one http://www.csgshop.com/product.php?id_product=64
-5/16 or 8mm round wooden rod (from any hardware store)
-PCB etching supplies if you are etching your own board. Otherwise just use a bread board. Instructions
Print 1x:
-Servo mount
-Arduino holder (I got this off thingiverse but can't find the page)
-Battery mount (this is just the arduino holder, stop printing before the arduino mounts start printing). Print 2x:
-Wheels (made from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21486 ) Assembly is pretty easy. The wooden rods should be a tight fit through the square holes but if not a bit of hot glue helps keep them in place. Use some thin wire to attach the wheels to the servos. Download the code and PCB files
https://github.com/jdorweiler/BalancingRobot Getting the robot to balance will still take a bit of work because of small differences in printed parts and servos. The main file in the Arduino sketch has a block of parameters to play with. These are the setpoint angle where the robot is balanced and the aggressive and conservative PID parameters. Its pretty much guess and check for those but I've left the ones that worked for me.

description.text:
I worked out that the 'perimeter width test' from the reprap.org wiki only really tested for dimensional correctness in the x axis, and I wanted a test part where I could measure the sizes achieved in x and y for male and female holes. Circles are hard to detect error in just 1 axes, so a male and female 10mm 'plug and socket' arrangement is perfect! Print this using your default settings, the male piece should measure right on 10mm in x and y and the female socket should also measure 10x10mm internally. Instructions incuding a comprehensive 'how to' on the correct way of achieving the correct size:
http://mechasonics.blogspot.com.au/2014/02/calibrating-3d-printed-sizes-in-x-y-axes.html
See http://mechasonics.blogspot.com.au/2014/02/calibrating-3d-printed-sizes-in-x-y-axes.html

title: Dimpler - The iPhone camera saver for thin cases

description.text:
I am a big fan of ultra thin phone cases, but iPhone's protruding camera invites dirt and possible scratches when you lay it down on a flat surface. This is, unless you create the saving dimple!

  • Print Dimpler
  • Decide where on the case you want the dimple. The Apple logo is a good location.
  • Stick strips of tape (Scotch Magic tape works) on and around the dimple area on the. This will buffer the heat and prevent sooting inside of the case
  • Mark the dimple location on the tape
  • Using a lighter, evenly warm the inside of the case over the tape for 3 seconds.
  • Immediately position the Dimpler over the marked spot and press! - Make sure the dimple is facing outside the case
  • Hold for 10 seconds.

title: RDQ Mach 1 Freestyle GoPro Mount with Battery on Top

description.text:
25 degree GoPro Session Mount and top plate for the RDQ Mach 1. You have to turn the top plate 180 on the Mach 1 but with this mount you can put your battery on top! Mount designed to hold 3mm antenna tubes for RX, battery strap, and Gopro session all in one. The battery pad section is designed to hold the 3M foam landing pads for battery cushion. Any piece of 10mm foam will work though.

the four screws for the top plate are used along with one zip tie in the middle to fasten this mount to Mach 1 top plate. Theres even a little box cutout for the zip tie end to fit into after tightening.

Work in progress more angles to come soon.

Justice League Batman Cowl STL Version 2.0

I was not happy with my version 1 as it wasnt as accurate as I would like, so I went back and fixed the following areas based on newer screenshots released from the movie... jaw/cheek, eyes, neck and ears where all updated for a better look than my previous effort.

This is print ready as one piece and would make a lovely display piece... but if anybody wishes to cut the face out and make it a wearable cowl... please do :) It should fit up to a 24 inch head... As said its one piece, but anybody with a 3d printer and programmes should have no problems cutting this up and adding supports to accommodate your machines build size. And if you have a smaller head then you can make the file smaller.

I hope this brings plenty of joy to many batman fans around the world. And would love to see all your printed cowls in here.

As a famous Batman said in 89... "I want you to tell all your friends about me..." So let everybody know they can grab themselves this cowl for free here. Have Fun

title: Tronxy P802MA Belt Clamp / Tensioner / SC8UU Bushing

description.text:
Edit 10October2017 The belt channel has been deepened by 4mm to better align the belt.

I designed this to lower the bottom half of the X axis belt in X Carriage type systems. Specifically, this was designed as a replacement for the one I originally designed for my creation here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2520345

My original design held the belt to high and caused binding issues. I've redesigned the clamp and combined it with a 2 piece bearing bushing that takes the place of the bottom SC8UU bushing. To use it you'll need 4 x M4 screws to secure the top and bottom half of the part.

This was designed to work with my Tronxy P802MA and I don't know if it will work with other models.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7gW5aWCHXSM

Classic wooden puzzle - now in plastic!
I found my old wooden one and decided it would be a great way to learn OpenSCAD.  I tried to make it as parametric as possible, and the default settings will print one the same size as my original wooden one.
Included is my first ever attempt at OpenSCAD and pre-rendered STL's for both a single plate (139mm x 120mm) and individual pieces using a 13mm width.
Originally I designed this from scratch.  Then I searched here to see if one was already uploaded.  I decided to make this a derivative of relet's Parametric Burr Puzzle Module as that is the closest thing to this puzzle, and I think you could make this one from his module.
UPDATE:  FIxed the STL's so they are sitting on the origin plane and not under it. (Not sure if that makes a difference for anyone)

Print either 1x plate
or: 6x long pieces,
16x short pieces,
and 2x key pieces. Assemble!
