Jesus is sitting on a rock called the “Cold Stone” and waiting to be crucified on Golgotha. This image of devotion invites the believer to meditate on the sufferings endured by Christ. description.text: Created a version based off the 30mm model with a stronger neck, and then flattened out the contact patch. You are forcing the part to bend to make contact with the original design, which seems to make the neck even weaker. There is an angle at the back side, so if you fit this flush with your desk edge it won't lay flat. I have a small space to grab on, so I don't come close to the back so I used this space to gain strength on that weak joint.

The original design had a very weak neck. This is a problem for most, but really a problem if you have a desk that is a traditional table top supported by a box type support structure. This gives me 28mm space only at the edge. It wouldn't be a big problem if the part was stronger, and I didn't feel like re-designing based on the small space I have to work with. I imported the mesh into Fusion 360, drew some sketches on the bodies, extruded, combined it all, and wala. This is my first time working with an existing STL, and I was shocked how easy Fusion 360 makes it.

title: A.E.G. G.IV - First World War Airplane / Avion de la Première Guerre mondiale
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(Le français suit l'anglais)

The Allgemeine Elektrizitäts Gesellschaft (A.E.G.) G.IV bomber went into general
use with the German Air Force in 1917. Because of its relatively short range,
the G.IV served mainly as a tactical bomber, and operated close to the front lines.
The G.IV flew both day and night operations, but, as the war progressed, was
restricted increasingly to night missions. A.E.G. units operated in France,
Romania, Greece, and Italy.

The A.E.G. G.IV found at the Canada Aviation and Space Museum was transported to Canada in 1919 as a war trophy and has remained in the country ever since. It is the only
surviving multi-engine German aircraft from the First World War and it is the only surviving aircraft from this period covered in the unique German “night lozenge” camouflage pattern.

For more information about the A.E.G. G.IV please visit:
https://ingeniumcanada.org/aviation/collection-research/artifact-aeg-giv.php

Note: This model is mainly meant to be viewed in a virtual environment using computer software. You can try printing it off, though we cannot guarantee the quality. For educational activities that this model can be used in, please visit: https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/museums/education/3D-aircrafts.php

Our terms of use can be found at: https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/doc/content/cstmc/CSTMC%20terms%20of%20use%203D%20ENG.pdf

Le bombardier Allgemeine Elektrizitäts Gesellschaft (A.E.G.) G.IV a été mis en service dans l’armée de l’air allemande en 1917. En raison de son rayon d’action relativement court, il a surtout été utilisé pour des missions de bombardement tactique près du front. L’A.E.G. G.IV a servi à réaliser des opérations de jour et de nuit, mais, avec le temps, on l’a de plus en plus réservé aux missions nocturnes. Il a été utilisé en France, en Roumanie, en Grèce et en Italie.

L’A.E.G. G.IV du Musée de l’aviation et de l’espace du Canada a été expédié au Canada comme trophée de guerre en 1919 et est demeuré ici depuis. C’est le seul avion allemand à plusieurs moteurs utilisé pendant la Première Guerre mondiale qui existe toujours et le seul appareil de cette période qui porte encore le distinctif camouflage de nuit à losanges.

Pour obtenir un complément d’information sur le A.E.G. G.IV, visitez le site

comments.author: JOEPRUSA

comments.text:
Hi JOEPRUSA
We've scanned and created 3D models of a few items. For the plane models we proposed that they be mostly used in an electronic way and our partners scaled them in 3D Studio originally for purposes in a game engine, so it's a pretty arbitrary size. I assume your question of scale was in terms of 3D printing? If so, prior to printing you can establish the size you'd like since any 3D tool has a scale tool which will uniformly scale the model up or down to absolutely any size without risk of file degradation - 3D doesn't care about size.
Hope this helps and we'd love to know what you do with the file.
Ingenium - Canada's Museums of Science and Innovation

title: HICTOP LCD on the bottom
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I am so spoiled by my Rostock and Original Prusa i3 having the LCD on the base that I decided to see what I could do for the HICTOP. I also find that having the LCD on top of the frame meant that it limited what could be done to the top :-)
I first tried to remix the Prusa design but quickly found that the display stood too tall and interfered with the Y-Axis travel.

The end result of all this frustration was an LCD case that could be mounted to the front 2020 rail or if needs must, stand alone.

Oh yes, I have even made the reset accessible (why did HICTOP leave that out?) and the SD slot is much cleaner and easier to "hit" when inserting a card.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1618

Infill:

30%

Notes:

ABS.

Mounting the LCD

I designed the case with 4 mounting posts. But really only the bottom two should be used. If you put screws in the top posts, you may have problems fitting the top to the bottom.

Assembiing the case

The case is designed to be friction fitted. There are no fasteners of any type used to connect the top to the bottom.

Knobs?

I did not design or modify any knob for this project. Instead, I simply grabbed the one from the i3 MK2s design files (It was not the same as the one that came with my printer, but what the hey)

Once again Fusion 360

3 years ago when I started 3D printing, I knew nothing about 3D design or 3D tools.
Fusion 360 is powerful enough to get the job done and there are many good tutorials on the "correct" way to use it.

So nowadays when I see something I need I just sit down and design it.

comments.text: After printing this, I found that my display (stock 3DP-17) won't fit.  The LCD circuit board (green) is ~1mm lower.  I'm going to see if I can grind out a small channel with my Dremel to see if that will work.  I may have to do a remix, though.  Will update once I get it assembled.
comments.author: GrueMaster

comments.text:
I should have mentioned that this may be the case. I have found that the standard HICTOP Display is larger than the standard RepRap discount display. This did not matter when using the HICTOP mount since it was built with a lot of tolerance.
Since the display case has some severe restrictions on height and width (due to the clearance of the bed) and I wanted the case to be friction fit, I had to select dimensions that would be very close. I made the decision to base the case on the standard RepRap Discount Display since it was slightly smaller than the HICTOP one.
Feel free to do a remix, just watch for the clearance on Height and width.
Oh, for me I simply swapped the HICTOP display for a RepRap display I had in a case with more room to use for Arduino projects or other controller experiments.

comments.text: David Laserscanner works differently from Kinect. It uses a line laser and a webcam to scan in a 3D object. I have a Fitbit Force and love it but unfortunately have succumbed to the dreaded rash.  I threw this together in Sketchup to see if it would protect against the rash.  It just fits on the back of the wristband - the little protrusion should fit into the charging port.  
I printed one (v7) and it fits the Fitbit Force perfectly.  It didn't prevent my rash as I think my problem is with the screws and it's harder to cover those.  This comes with no guarantees that it will prevent the skin reaction, but it will protect your skin from the charging port.  
This prints without sharp edges, but it's a bit more comfortable if you sand the corners down a bit.

Try printing with a few shells and at best resolution you can (i.e., 0.1mm if possible).  I don't think it's thick enough to really use any infill so I don't know if that will make a difference.  Sanding it down after printing will make it more comfortable.  You can print it on its back but printing it upright with a raft also works pretty well.

author: diversidadimpresa

description.text:
I was tired to spend so much time to level my bed every change I made so I've looked around for a way to automate the work. Found few thing that I didn't like too much, so I decided to start from scratch and design my way to do it.
The light bulb has switched on when I remembered that foot activated door lock (you know, push pin to lock, push lever to release), simple and effective. Just what I was looking for...
I just had to scale it to right measure and add an (optional) 9g servo to automate the lever unlock and some minor Marlin firmware configuration, 'et voilà', no more or less complicated mechanisms, switches, sensors etc.
It's a Public Domain project, so if someone will help to improve it I'll be grateful.

Printer:

D-bot

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print all as in pictures, no support required.
I've made use of PET-G charged with graphite, a very robust material.
However you can use ABS, PLA etc., it's not required a heavy duty, after all.
I'm used to make infill always at 100%, I want to be sure my printed objects are strong.

How you can see in the images, the 'thing' is conceptually very simple.
The upper screw is the bed leveling screw (length at your choice) surrounded by a spring whose strength is just enough to sustain the bed and heater weight.
When you push the four levers, the upper screws unlock and the bed rises, you don't care how much.
Next, you issue a G28-G29 sequence that moves the nozzle to the four corners defined in firmware, lowering Z each time to its end-stop (preset to +0.20mm, see Hints below); this way the bed goes down pushed from nozzle and stay there when you rise the nozzle, withheld by the screw locked in place by the lever.
Game over! You have a perfectly (almost) planar bed respect to the nozzle.

• Remember to fine tuning the Z end-stop so the bed is at +0.20mm from nozzle (or whatever layer height you use); every future leveling shall lead to that height.
  • The support fixing holes are suitable for 2020, 2040 and 3030 profiles.
  • Not usable on slipping bed like Prusa, obviously, too many solicitations
  • For better results I'd suggest to build the lever with aluminium or, better, iron to achieve durability and precision of lock. Not a tough work...
Quotes and holes

This is optional

Here the intriguing part come .
With the help of four 9g servos (they are cheap nowadays) you can automate the lever release operation, driving them to a CCW 15° and back to 0°.
You can connect them to the same output pin, due to low current required (about 200mA, each one due to low force necessary); this way you take up only one pin from your board (see schematic below).
Marlin mods:
Locate in config.h
'//#define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 0 // Defaults to SERVO 0 connector.'
'//#define Z_SERVO_ANGLES {70,0} // Z Servo Deploy and Stow angles'

and uncomment the two lines; modify also that 70,0 to 15,0. You'd have now:

'#define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 0 // Defaults to SERVO 0 connector.'
'#define Z_SERVO_ANGLES {15,0} // Z Servo Deploy and Stow angles'

Locate in config.h

'//#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_3POINT'
'//#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_LINEAR'
'#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR'
'//#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_UBL'
'//#define MESH_BED_LEVELING'

and comment out all options, so auto bed leveling is disabled; we don't need it anymore.

That's all. If you execute G28-G29 sequence you'll see it working...

Few things
  • n. 1 screw M3x40mm (indicative) or same length iron pin
  • n. 1 screw M5x10mm
  • n. 2 springs from ball point pen
  • n. 1 iron pin d. 2mm l. 30mm
  • patience as needed...

The images are explanatory.
Cut away 25% of the lower spring and insert it into lower hole after inserted the lever, then push inside with the bottom side M5 screw.

title: Franke Ascona SP3308 Tap Valve Adaptor

description.text:
If you have a dripping Franke Ascona Tap, or maybe one of their other taps fitted with a SP3308 1/4 turn ceramic valve, you may find it difficult to remove the old valve. This is because the valve doesn't have a conventional hex head, it's rounded with just 2 flat edges 12mm apart, like in the picture. The valve is also inset into the tap body, so it's very difficult to get an open ended spanner onto it.

I tried removing the valve but the spanner just slipped off. I also tried mole grips, adjustable wrenches etc, but nothing would give the grip I needed and the valve was starting to get mashed. Luckily I was inside my 5 year warranty, so Franke customer service very nicely sent me their 4013R adaptor - if you're outside your warranty, you can buy the tool from online retailers for £12, but looking at it, I thought there must be a better way.

So, here is my Franke SP3308 Valve Removal Tool. It's a really simple design and fits inside a 17mm socket. Print it with 100% infill - I used clear PET. The plastic doesn't have to be "that" hard because it works by compression - it can't escape because the socket holds it all in place and that is what gives you the grip on the tap head. It took less than 10 minutes to print, costs about 10p in plastic and works a treat.

Shown are pictures of the valve, the Franke metal adaptor, my plastic adaptor, plus the whole thing fitted into a 17mm socket.

Note that Franke must've realised there was a design problem - the replacement valves came with an improved conventional hex head that you can fit a regular socket over.

Tools required
1) My adaptor
2) A deep 17mm hex socket (preferably one with a straight "HEX" inner, not one of the multi adaptors)
3) A socket wrench
4) A T8 Torx bit to remove the small grub screw which holds the tap handle on the valve
This thing was made with Tinkercad.
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5Wp95v23bk4

description.text: These are 8 lantern rings depicted in DC comics. Although there is a 9th white lantern ring, I do not know how to recreate it geometrically. The default ring size is 21mm so scale it to your size. The rings in the picture were printed with a MakerBot Replicator 2 with 175mm PLA.
